title: 110_s1582
content: The Act may be cited as the "Hydrographic Services Improvement Act Amendments of 2008". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892) is amended to define "hydrographic data" as information acquired through various surveying methods and used in providing hydrographic services. "Hydrographic services" are defined as the management, maintenance, interpretation, certification, and dissemination of bathymetric and hydrographic data. The curr_chunk discusses the certification, dissemination, and development of various types of geospatial and nautical information, including the production of nautical charts and databases. It also mentions related activities and defines the Coast and Geodetic Survey Act. The Administrator is responsible for various functions related to geospatial and nautical information, including the production of nautical charts and databases. The Administrator's responsibilities include producing nautical charts and databases. Section 303 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 is amended to enhance marine transportation safety and promote environmental stewardship. The Administrator may procure, operate vessels and equipment for hydrographic data acquisition, design real-time monitoring systems, provide hydrographic services for navigation safety, conservation of coastal resources, and emergency response. The Administrator may create joint centers with other entities to support resumption of commerce in emergencies, disasters, and homeland security needs, and award contracts for hydrographic data acquisition. SEC. 4. HYDROGRAPHIC SERVICES REVIEW PANEL. The panel will consist of 15 voting members appointed by the Administrator, with nonvoting members including the Co-directors of the Center for Coastal and Ocean Mapping/Joint Hydrographic Center and up to 2 NOAA employees. Voting members must be qualified in disciplines related to hydrographic data, marine transportation, port administration, and other relevant fields. SEC. 5. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 306 of the Hydrographic Services Improvement Act of 1998 (33 U.S.C. 892d) is amended to authorize appropriations. Authorized appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions include $55,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $56,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $57,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $58,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. Additionally, funding for hydrographic surveys contracts amounts to $32,130,000 for fiscal year 2009, $32,760,000 for fiscal year 2010, $33,390,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $34,020,000 for fiscal year 2012. Operating hydrographic survey vessels owned by the United States requires $25,900,000 for fiscal year 2009. Authorized appropriations for nautical mapping and charting functions include $55,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $56,000,000 for fiscal year 2010, $57,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $58,000,000 for fiscal year 2012. Funding for geodetic functions amounts to $32,640,000 for fiscal year 2009, $33,280,000 for fiscal year 2010, $33,920,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $34,560,000 for fiscal year 2012. Tide and current measurement functions are allocated $27,000,000 for fiscal year 2009, $27,500,000 for fiscal year 2010, $28,000,000 for fiscal year 2011, and $28,500,000 for fiscal year 2012. Additionally, $75,000,000 is designated for acquiring a replacement hydrographic survey vessel capable of staying at sea continuously for at least 30 days. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZED NOAA CORPS STRENGTH. The total number of authorized commissioned officers in the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration Commissioned Officer Corps will increase from 321 to 379 effective October 1, 2009, subject to certain conditions being met.
